qas.question: What is the term for transit energy flowing as a result of differences in temperature?
What type of heat transmission can propagate through a vacuum?
What object emits thermal radiation in the X-ray spectrum?
The visible, ultraviolet and X-ray spectra are all above what spectrum?
How does heat propagate through a vaccuum?
What object emits heat in the x-ray spectrum?

plausible_answers.text: due to the vibration of its molecules at a given temperature

qas.question: How is heat associated with emission from an object?

plausible_answers.text: visible, ultraviolet, and even X-ray regions

qas.question: What spectra is heat extended into?

plausible_answers.text: is only a coincidence based on typical (comparatively low) temperatures often found near the surface of planet Earth.

qas.question: What is the association of heat with thermal radiation?

context: <a0_0>Heat<a0_0/> is energy in transit that <b4_0>flows due to temperature difference<b4_0/>. Unlike heat transmitted by thermal conduction or thermal convection, <a1_0>thermal radiation<a1_0/> can propagate through a vacuum. Thermal radiation is characterized by a particular spectrum of many wavelengths that is associated with emission from an object, <b6_0>due to the vibration of its molecules at a given temperature<b6_0/>. Thermal radiation can be emitted from objects at any wavelength, and at very high temperatures such radiations are associated with spectra far above the <a3_0>infrared<a3_0/>, extending into <b7_0>visible, ultraviolet, and even X-ray regions<b7_0/> (i.e., <a2_0><b5_0>the solar corona<b5_0/><a2_0/>). Thus, the popular association of infrared radiation with thermal radiation <b8_0>is only a coincidence based on typical (comparatively low) temperatures often found near the surface of planet Earth.
